body: I have only one minor request: include the Java source for the corresponding jar. When you do, squash all the commit, no new PG needed to merge.

This protection on the rule isn't much protection at all: one can delete the trigger or the action leaving the rule in a bad state.

What's perhaps necessary is a sealing operation on a package instead, that prevent accidentally deleting, updating, or disabling all assets in the sealed package (note, I'm inventing a new concept, sealing, and allowing rules, triggers, and actions to be nested in a package).

So I've implemented this - the impetus was seeing the horrendous code one has to write to programmatically deal with deleting or updating a rule.

When one created/runs a docker action in openwhisk, the executable does read and write to std in/out. Using one of the base images we provide means the action benefits from the built in proxy. As such, I'm inclined to close this.

@rabbah What would be the problem to use `.json` instead of `.js` in the web api url `.../action.json` ?
I think using `.json` is more clear to talk about `application/json` instead of `.js` or maybe I'm missing something.

Great comments @csantanapr. We can add CORS support - it's in the controller already, just have to wrap these new routes with it -- I think at cursory glance. Yes images could be supported. I opted not to include it here but did try it (with an svg). I agree on POST but adding it without supporting form-urlencoded input will be broken, so we'll have to add both at once. Lastly, it's .js not .json deliberately. This is raised by Markus also. It would make projecting a JSON value (string) for example an error (one must use a text extension - similarly for the other value types). So it's a convenience so that if one is projecting top level fields or nested fields they're not constantly changing both the extension and the projection at the same time. I can be swayed toward stricter form though. I'd like to consider all but the last as additive features to address as future enhancements.

EDIT: convinced `.js` renamed to `.json` - and magic removed @csantanapr @markusthoemmes.

@rabbah My comment was just feedback for additive future enhancements to discuss, and possible to break into different issues/PRs.
And possible to have other contributors work on these enhancements.
No magic 🌮 🌮

Hello @chadbrewbaker, have you seen this blog post about running binaries on OpenWhisk using the `openwhisk/dockerskeleton` image? 
https://www.ibm.com/blogs/bluemix/2017/01/docker-bluemix-openwhisk/

This approach allows you to easy execute any binary on the platform (that's compatible with the architecture) as shown here: http://jamesthom.as/blog/2017/01/16/openwhisk-docker-actions/
@jasonpet - the whisk object references are removed in PR #1730.. it's in review state now

@rabbah 
I wasn't aware this was done but I just tested it and it doesn't appear that the kind is being returned in the api call to fetch all the actions.  I know work was done to expose sequence actions from plain actions in that api call. 

Retrieving the "kind" at the top level is still needed for performance reasons, as well as the memory and timeout included.  Those are the three fields currently needed for the Manage page that require the additional fetch for each action a user has. So the initialization of the Manage page is pretty slow right now due to those additional fetches. 

In the api call that returns all the actions as a list each action object only has
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19595703/22254328/47976e2a-e222-11e6-9012-73b8e2082744.png)
done - closing
Getting more reports from users being hit with this problem, like using a parameter with value `Aurélien` the `é` not being handle correctly.

I believe that this is tied to #252. We really need to get someone to take a look at this. I don't think that this should be too hard to fix. I think the problem is that they are running OpenWhisk in the wrong codepage they should be running in UTF-8. My guess is that they are probably defaulting to ISO8859-1 (Latin 1) when they should be using Unicode.
I think that this really needs to get fixed and I think it is tied to #362 as well.
There are many instances of this bug - fixing this will close the most issues in one commit :1st_place_medal:
I was incorrect above.  As you can clearly see the action has the field "exec" which has the action's kind, which is "nodejs:6".  Closing this issue now.

Here's a hint: actions via zip files work. This rules out (as both @psuter and I confirmed with separate unit tests) that it's not the action container but likely the interface between the container and the invoker for exchanging arguments.

Ok so this means that it is probably the code that is reading the files. It may be reading it in the wrong codepage. Check to see if they have hardcoded that. If the code that reads the files is written in Java then the default codepage is probably ISO8859-1. I don't believe that UTF-8 is the default you need to explicit state the encoding.
found it!
Don't keep it a secret !!!

Confirmed duplicate of #252.

I confirmed a couple of issues were duplicates and closed them (and tests cover them).
The Java action proxy, and the python proxy for the other runtimes will need to be patched. These are confirmed to be in the containers themselves, and not the Invoker (as was the case with node.js). #1757 fixes the node.js actions as a first step.

EDIT: Java actions also fixed in same PR.
closed

@rabbah Usually is always good to ask politely for CLA.
If person doesn't do it for what ever reason in 1 or 2 days and it's not a significant change, I would just merge the PR.

This get's people walking down the process to contribute more. Also if we don't ask for CLA and accept, and have seeing the case where the person will submit a second PR with more significant changes and if we then ask for an CLA then they complaint that the first PR we didn't ask for CLA.

I thought @paulcastro was going to merge days ago.
I will merge now I guess.

The fix for #252 is necessary but not sufficient to fix swift (and python) actions. The proxy needs to handle utf-8 encoding, where it currently does not; pr #1757 includes the required invoker side fix.
Thanks!
